say.translation[0].definitions[0].defini: to express an idea, feeling, thought etc using words
say.translation[0].definitions[0].exampl: What a silly thing to say!
a terrible/silly/strange etc thing to say
I’ve said I’m sorry – what more do you want?
Can I go, Mum? Oh, please say yes!
He looked as if he was going to say something.
I wished I had said nothing about Jordi.
Does anyone else have anything to say?
Although he didn’t say so, it was clear that he was in pain.
What makes you say that (=why do you think that)?
A spokesman said that the company had improved its safety standards.
I always said I would buy a motorbike when I had enough money.
I would like to say how much we appreciate your hard work.
‘Why did she leave?’ ‘I don’t know – she didn’t say.’
What did you say to her?
‘This is strange, ’ he said to himself.
Nina said to meet her at 4.30.
I’d like to say a few words (=make a short speech).
‘So what are your plans now?’ ‘I’d rather not say.’
say.translation[0].definitions[1].defini: to give information in the form of written words, numbers, or pictures – used about signs, clocks, letters, messages etc
say.translation[0].definitions[1].exampl: The clock said twenty past three.
It says here they have live music.
He received a letter saying that the appointment had been cancelled.
The label says to take one tablet before meals.
The card doesn’t even say who sent the flowers.
say.translation[0].definitions[2].defini: used to talk about what someone means
say.translation[0].definitions[2].exampl: What do you think the writer is trying to say in this passage?
So what you’re saying is, there’s none left.
All I’m saying is that it might be better to wait a while.
I’m not saying it’s a bad idea.
say.translation[0].definitions[2].note_b: Say is usually used in the progressive in this meaning
say.translation[0].definitions[3].defini: used to talk about something that people think is true
say.translation[0].definitions[3].exampl: Well, you know what they say – blood’s thicker than water.
The rest, as they say, is history.
They say that she has been all over the world.
they say/people say/ it is said (that)
It is said that he was a spy during the war.
they say/people say/ it is said (that)
He’s said to be the richest man in the world.
somebody is said to be something/do something
say.translation[0].definitions[4].defini: to show clearly that something is true about someone or something’s character
say.translation[0].definitions[4].exampl: The kind of car you drive says what kind of person you are.
The fact that she never apologized says a lot about (=shows very clearly) what kind of person she is.
It said a lot for the manager  (=it showed that he is good) that the team remained confident despite losing.
These results don’t say much for the quality of teaching  (=they show that it is not very good).
say.translation[0].definitions[5].defini: to show what someone is really feeling or thinking, especially without using words
say.translation[0].definitions[5].exampl: The look on her face said ‘I love you.’
say.translation[0].definitions[6].defini: to speak the words that are written in a play, poem, or prayer
say.translation[0].definitions[6].exampl: Can you say that line again, this time with more feeling?
I’ll say a prayer for you.
say.translation[0].definitions[7].defini: to pronounce a word or sound
say.translation[0].definitions[7].exampl: How do you say your last name?
say.translation[0].definitions[8].defini: used when suggesting or supposing that something might happen or be true
say.translation[0].definitions[8].exampl: If we put out, say, twenty chairs, would that be enough?
Let’s say your plan fails, then what?
Just say you won the lottery – what would you do?
say.translation[0].definitions[8].note_b: Say is usually used in the imperative or with let’s in this meaning
say.translation[0].note_box[0].sections[: I just wanted to say thank you for being there.
It was probably too late to say sorry.
Some parents are unable to say no to their children.
I was about to say something to him when he looked up and smiled.
She stopped abruptly, suddenly afraid to say the words aloud.
If you don’t know the answer, don’t be afraid to say so.
a terrible/stupid/odd etc thing to say
I know it’s a terrible thing to say, but I wish he’d just go away.
He usually has something to say about just about everything.
The principal said a few words to us
You use say with speech marks (‘’) when quoting the exact words that someone used
You use say (that)  when reporting what someone saidAfter said, the verb in the other clause is usually also in the past tense
She said that she was sorry she was late
Joe said he would be back soon
He told us a long story
You tell someone about something that has happened
She told me about the accident
You use tell someone (that) when reporting what someone said  After told, the verb in the other clause is usually also in the past tense
I told them that I was sorry
The teacher told me I could go home
He told that he was sorry
say.translation[0].note_box[2].sections[: to say something
to tell someone something, using words
‘I really ought to go, ’ she said.
Lauren said she’d probably be late.
state
to say something, especially in a definite or formal way – used in official contexts
The witness stated that he had never seen the woman before.
Please state your name and address.
announce
to publicly tell people about something
The chairman announced his resignation.
The results will be announced tomorrow.
We will announce the winners next Sunday.
They were announcing the train times over the loudspeaker system.
declare
to say something very firmly
‘My personal life is none of your business, ’ she declared.
mention
to talk about someone or something, especially without giving many details
Did Tom mention anything about what happened at school?
Your name was mentioned!
express
to let someone know your feelings by putting them into words
Young children often find it difficult to express their emotions.
comment
to say what your opinion is about someone or something
The prime minister was asked to comment on the crisis.
note/remark
to say that you have noticed that something is true – used especially in formal writing
We have already noted that most old people live alone.
Someone once remarked that the problem with computers is that they only give you answers.
add
to say something more, after what has already been said
He added that he thought it could be done fairly cheaply.
point out
to mention something that seems particularly important or relevant
Dr Graham points out that most children show some signs of abnormal behaviour.
It’s worth pointing out that few people actually die of this disease.
air
to talk about your opinions, worries, or the things you disagree about
The programme will give listeners the chance to air their views about immigration.
Workers were able to air their grievances.
to talk publicly about your feelings or about whether you approve or disapprove of something
The president has already voiced his support for the proposal.
She voiced concern for the safety of the hostages.
different ways of saying something
whisper
to say something very quietly, using your breath rather than your full voice
‘Don’t wake the baby, ’ Jenny whispered.
mumble
to say something quietly without pronouncing the words clearly
He mumbled his thanks.
mutter
to say something quietly, especially when you are annoyed but do not want someone to hear you complaining
‘This is ridiculous, ’ he muttered under his breath.
She muttered something about having to go home early.
murmur
to say something in a soft slow gentle voice
She stroked his hair and murmured, ‘Don’t worry. You’ll be all right.’
growl
to say something in a low angry voice
‘As I was saying, ’ Lewis growled, ‘it needs to be finished today.’
snarl
to say something in a nasty angry way
‘Get out of my way!’ he snarled.
exclaim
to say something suddenly and loudly
‘How beautiful!’ she exclaimed.
blurt out
to suddenly say something without thinking, especially something embarrassing or secret
It was partly nervousness that had made him blurt out the question.
stammer/stutter
to speak with a lot of pauses and repeated sounds, because you have a speech problem, or because you are nervous or excited
‘I’ll, I’ll only be a m-moment, ’ he stammered.
say.translation[1].definitions[0].defini: the right to take part in deciding something
say.translation[1].definitions[0].exampl: The chairman has the final say (=has the right to make the final decision about something).
The workers had no say in how the factory was run.
say.translation[2].definitions[0].defini: used to express surprise, or to get someone’s attention so that you can tell them something
say.translation[2].definitions[0].exampl: Say, haven’t I seen you before somewhere?
